content.description: Somewhat reminiscent of Smith cobbles, steep and loose. Missing the clip at the second bolt can lead to a ground fall; 'nuff said.
content.protection: 4 bolts, bolted anchor.
content.location: Around the corner from Overhung, difficult to see as you approach. Rap the route.

content.description: Start as for Overhung, but after the first bolt tend left and up the steep, thinner line. Old bolts of unknown origin make this a questionable route, at best. The grade is just a guess, Unknown has not climbed this is some time.
content.protection: 3 bolts, thin rack.
content.location: Same start as for Overhung, but after the first bolt tend left and up the steep, thinner line. Old bolts of unknown origin make this a questionable lead, at best.

content.description: Fun climb out a steep headwall. FA by Jake Whittaker and Travis Klawin in the late 90's.
content.protection: 5 bolts and intermittent gear. There is a bolted anchor. Condition unknown.
content.location: Start with the dark flare of 'Nothing Special', then exit left and up the overhanging headwall peppered with 5 bolts.

climbs.name: Therapeutic Recreation
climbs.fa: Tim Laughlin, Stan Miller, Todd Burrill

content.description: Start in the wide corner (Peabody). Traverse left (clip the first bolt of Porous Tactics) and over the arete lip and up past 2 more (old and rusty) bolts on Arms Control, finding gear on the way. This line is somewhat contrived, but follows an obvious weakness in the rock. Great fun, eats nuts and tri-cams
content.protection: 3 old rusty bolts, rack to 2", double set of nut helps, slings.
content.location: Start in 'Peabody', immediately follow the left traversing weakness in the rock out to the arete, around, and up.

climbs.name: Stegosaurus
climbs.fa: John Bald, Randy Dewees, Jack Fisher

content.description: Another line where you know you are at elevation. A good test of your power endurance. The last 15 feet, just when you are really feeling it, pro disappears. Fun.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3". Doubles in .5- 2"; nuts rule on this one.
content.location: The left arching crack. Starts with an easy,  steep 10' wall and then a ramp to the base of the business. Lower from the anchors at the top.

content.description: Start as on Perineal Massage, as the wall steepens move right to the overhanging right face. Try and find gear placements between the bolts.
content.protection: Gear to 1" and 5 bolts.
content.location: Same start as Perineal Massage, the right side is overhung. It can be difficult to see the bolts from the ground. Rap from anchor.

content.description: This is mentioned because we all look at it and think..."Is that any good?" No. Dirty, loose, not fun; and difficult to protect. People have been known to use it to access the anchors for 'Lightning Crack'. Don't.
content.protection: Standard rack to 5"
content.location: The corner crack at the top of the dirt and scree slope to the right of Lightning Crack. Walk off or rap from chains on Lightning Crack.

content.description: Start just left off a shallow left facing corner which is just left of Nothing Special. Follow three bolts meandering left across the wall to the arete and up to a big sloping ledge. Climb up to just under the obvious crack that cuts its way through the overhanging head wall. Clip a bolt and start up juggy liebacks to a short rest with a marginal knee bar. Clip another bolt and attack the overhanging fingercrack above using powerful dynamic moves and thin face holds to the lip. Now save some juice for the splitter head wall above and finish with a pump at the two bolt anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Cams; double .3” to 1”
content.location: Just to the left of Nothing Special and Undertow.

content.description: Dirty crack in the back left of the recessed area right of 'Sober'. This could be a better line if it was cleaned/climbed more often. WIth so many other good lines here, this one just gets ignored. Give it a go!
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", doubles .75-2".
content.location: Dirty crack in the back left of the recessed area right of 'Sober'. Has been known to sprout bushes.

content.description: Another open project bolted by Travis Klawin in the 90's. Not much known. 3 bolts and intermittent gear. Steep and difficult.
content.protection: 3 bolts
content.location: Up the scree slope to the left of Nothing Special is an overhanging wall with 3 older bolts.There is a bolted anchor. Condition unknown.

climbs.name: Porous Tactics
climbs.fa: Tom Laughlin, John Bald, John Hassle, Craig Neilsen

content.description: One of the best at the crag, the line ascends a dark orange band of bullet rock. After the fourth bolt, step left onto the arete and find the painted hangers shared with 'Therapeutic Recreation'. Fun route finding with lots of options.
content.protection: 4 old rusty bolts.
content.location: The left wall of the Peapod alcove. Can start by either traversing in from the start of 'Peabody' (easier) or straight up from the lowest point (harder).

content.description:
The seam to the right of Stegosaurus leads straight up to a steep wall protected by 6 bolts. Pockets abound, choose the right ones to 'massage'. A fun steep line, one of those lines where you remember half way up that you are at 9,000 feet. Keep pulling!

All bolts replaced by ASCA in 08/2020
content.protection: Thin gear to 1", six bolts. Anchor at the top can not be seen from the ground.
content.location: Look for the left arching layback finger crack (Stegosaurus). Perineal Massage is just to the right. Anchors at the top

content.description:
Rope solo by Todd Swain in 1988 (!) this is a wonderful, pumpy, heady line. First bolt is 20' off the deck, very stiff getting to it. Two bolt mussy hook anchor is easy to set a top rope on. Starting in the crack to the right (Peapod) makes the line a little easier and the first bolt a lot closer.

All bolts replaced by ASCA in 08/2020
content.protection: 5  bolts, optional small finger sized piece for the top.
content.location: The vertical wall between Peapod and Peabody. Starting in the center adds some difficulty.

content.description: If you like it wide, jump in. Fists to OW to Chimney, can be dirty at times, cold and or wet in the spring, a fun grovel up the rock. Easier if you stay outside, but who climbs wide cracks to stay out of them?
content.protection: Cams 1-6" Doubles 3-6" Larger big bro's if you are not comfortable running it out a bit in the top of an easy (5.6?)chimney.
content.location: The left side crack in the alcove. Step up onto the bench and immediately get wide, wider, widest! Use the chains to climbers right (Porous Tactics) to lower.

content.description: Originally rated 10.b (in 1984) after many years and many broken holds, the consensus of the few stupid enough to trust the bolts is 10+. A very airy (rhymes with scary) start heading out a badly protected ramp. Look for gear. Still a lot of breaking rock.
content.protection: 4 old rusty bolts. Good climb, needs to be re-bolted as of 5/2014.
content.location: The arete/face to the left and around the corner from Lightning Crack. Find the easiest safest way up to the ramp. Watch for loose rock.

content.description: Start up difficult to protect easy boulder problem to a low angle bushy crack. at approximately 40' the business starts. Fingers to hands to offhands/fists, a left arching steep crack you wish went on for 1,000'! Just beautiful. Much harder then 10.b if you just use the crack. Eats nuts.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3". Doubles 1-3? Nuts and offset nuts work well. Shoulder slings, and a brush to clean if it is the first lead of the year. There are now anchors on top (you have to pull the lip to reach them, save a #2 for the lip)
content.location: The orange overhanging left arching crack, easily seen from the lower trail. The lower section occasionally needs pruning, can be very bushy.

content.description: Another line which needs to be climbed more to clean it up, it could be something more than 'Nothing Special'. Just to the left of 'Chips and Salsa' there is a dark slot/chimney. Often choked with munge and/or plant life. Hump your way through this to a too short fun hand/fist crack to the anchors shared with the two lines to the right.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", doubles 1-3". Slings help with the deep placements in the lower chimney. An optional 4" makes the fist crack feel a little more secure.
content.location: The large, dark pod/chimney going straight up to a wide hand crack. Ends on a large ledge sharing the anchor with Stegosaurus and Chips and Salsa.

climbs.name: Lightning Crack
climbs.fa: F.A. Rob Settlemire, Gary Adams  F.F.A Jim Yates, John Bald

content.description: An absolute gem. A zigzagging finger to hand to fist crack (5.9+) leads to the money; a thin finger bolt of lightning arching straight up to the hidden chains. One of the most obvious and eye catching lines on the crag.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3". Doubles .3-.75. Slings and nuts. Chains for anchor.
content.location: Look for the zigzag crack just past the overhung cobbled face in the large alcove up and towards the end of the rock band. Easily seen as you approach the climb. There is a small tree on a ledge where the substantial chains will be found. Easily rapped.

content.description: Variation of King Pin was actually climbed 2 years before King Pin. Instead of breaking right and up, head straight up the unprotected headwall directly towards the tree. Eliminates make it harder/softer.
content.protection: Toprope
content.location: Same as King Pin.

content.description: Face climb to 1 bolt, then moving up and right, scour the rock for pro, which is not great. A fun line, be comfortable at the grade due to the paucity of pro. This could almost be rated PG13.
content.protection: 1 older bolt, standard rack to 3", tricams in pods work well.
content.location: Look for the route 'Booze', 6 bolts on overhung cobbles. King Pin is the line to the left of this with one bolt 15' off the ground. Rap from the tree at the top. As of 5.2014 the sling in the tree was gone.

content.description: Squeezed in between 'Peon U' and 'Peabody', a line in it's own. Crux is soon after leaving the ground finding the sequence through the seemingly blank bulge. Harder than it looks. The name comes from James Egan, who upon breaking the crux hold, found that "It works better broken". HA!
content.protection: Toprope
content.location: Use the anchor from 'Peon U'. Starts on the bench where 'Peabody' begins, straight up, ending in the wide crack at the top.

content.description: Start low in the middle of the face with a left crimp rail, and right sidepull. Climb up on good crimps then traverse left and up by matching a gaston.
content.protection: 2 or 3 pads
content.location: Line traversing left on the ~15 foot Diamond-shaped boulder in the area below the rock wall Left of Peapod

content.description:
A steep face pocketed with just enough holds to make it a great climb. The start is protected by thin gear, be careful of rope drag. Was originally 11.a, but as the rock evolves (holds break) it has become harder. The start can be quite...thrilling.

Top

an

chors replaced by ASCA in 08/2020
content.protection: 5 older bolts and draws for the anchor.
content.location: Just to the left of Stegosaurus. Line goes straight up to the anchor shared with 'Stegosaurus' and 'Nothing Special'.

content.description: Another beautiful line by Travis Klawin. Reminiscent of Smith cobbles, a steep overhung line. Hard to find the way, a tough one to on-sight. It is not over after the lip, as the holds diminish after the third bolt.
content.protection: 6 bolts plus bolted anchor
content.location: The steep cobbled overhanging section with the shiny bolts. Hard to miss, your eye says "What's that", your head says "No way".

climbs.name: At Play On the Slabs of The Lord

content.description: From the Chains of Lightning Crack, work any number of meandering lines up the thin slabs below. Can be made as difficult as one may want.
content.protection: Sadly, toprope.
content.location: Below the small tree at the top of Lightning Crack.

climbs.name: Arms Control
climbs.fa: Dave Count, Rob Settlemire, Stan Miller

content.description:
Start on small tree at base of overhung 15' wall. Move straight up and over the lip, then trend right and up following the line of bolts. This goes solid 12a/b without the tree start. Bring a stick clip.

All bolts replaced by ASCA in 08/2020
content.protection: 6 bolts lead to two bolt anchored shared w/ Therapeutic Recreation.
content.location: The overhung face to the left of the Peapod alcove. There is a small bent tree at the base.
